thread.title: Hickenlooper votes for CO to keep excess pot tax revenue
thread.title_full: Hickenlooper votes for CO to keep excess pot tax revenue

title: Hickenlooper votes for CO to keep excess pot tax revenue
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Hickenlooper votes for CO to keep excess pot tax revenue In less than two weeks, Colorado voters will decide whether the state can keep about $66 million in marijuana tax revenue or they'll have to refund it to taxpayers. Post to Facebook Hickenlooper votes for CO to keep excess pot tax revenue In less than two weeks, Colorado voters will decide whether the state can keep about $66 million in marijuana tax revenue or they'll have to refund it to taxpayers.  //on9news.tv/1LPZNs5   Join the Conversation To   Hickenlooper votes for CO to keep excess pot tax revenue Mackenzie Concepcion, 4:47 p.m. MDT October 22, 2015 Gov. Hickenlooper voted in favor of Proposition BB, which would allow the state to keep excess marijuana tax revenue. (Photo: KUSA) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
DENVER – In less than two weeks, Colorado voters will decide whether the state can keep about $66 million in marijuana tax revenue or they'll have to refund it to taxpayers. 
Proposition BB, up for approval next month, would allow the state to retain and spend $66.1 million in excess pot tax revenue. 
Gov. John Hickenlooper cast his vote in support of Proposition BB on Thursday. He said passing the proposition would help education and regulation efforts. 
If the measure is passed, state officials said $40 million would go to school construction and $12 million would fund marijuana education. 
The remaining chunk of marijuana tax revenue has yet to be allocated. 
"All the pot revenue that comes in -- our goal is to regulate marijuana, to make sure our kids don't get access to marijuana and, as the voters originally intended, that we build buildings to improve our K-12 education," Hickenlooper said. 
Opponents to the measure have called it a tax hike. They say approving it would mean Coloradans would take home less money. 
If the proposition fails, $25 million would be refunded to tax payers, amounting about a $6 to $8 refund for most Coloradans. 
As for the rest of the money, $24 million would go to marijuana cultivators and $17 million would be refunded to marijuana purchasers through a temporary sales tax reduction.
